Title: Sn 1:1  The Snake
column4: Sn 1:1  The Snake  —  One who advances far along the path sloughs off the near shore and far, like a snake who sloughs off its skin.

Title: Sn 1:2  Dhaniya the Cattleman
column4: Sn 1:2  Dhaniya the Cattleman  —  A poetic dialogue contrasting the wealth and security of lay life with the wealth and security of a person who has lived the renunciate life to its culmination. If you have trouble relating to someone like Dhaniya who measures his wealth in cattle, then when reading this poem substitute stocks and bonds for cows and bulls, and economic downturn for rain.

Title: Sn 1:3  A Rhinoceros
column4: Sn 1:3  A Rhinoceros  —  If you can’t find a good teacher, it’s better to wander alone.

Title: Sn 1:4  To Kasi Bhāradvāja
column4: Sn 1:4  To Kasi Bhāradvāja  —  The Buddha answers a farmer who claims that monks do no useful work and so don’t deserve to eat.

Title: Sn 1:5  Cunda
column4: Sn 1:5  Cunda  —  Four different types of contemplatives and how to recognize them.

Title: Sn 1:6  Decline
column4: Sn 1:6  Decline  —  The various actions and attitudes that lead to spiritual decline.

Title: Sn 1:7  An Outcaste
column4: Sn 1:7  An Outcaste  —  Being an outcaste is a matter of behavior, not birth.

Title: Sn 1:8  Goodwill
column4: Sn 1:8  Goodwill  —  The practice of developing universal goodwill: the practices that form a foundation for the practice, the attitude of universal goodwill itself, and the steps that lead from goodwill to awakening.

Title: Sn 1:9  Hemavata
column4: Sn 1:9  Hemavata  —  The Buddha explains to a yakkha how one crosses over the flood.

Title: Sn 1:10  Āḷavaka
column4: Sn 1:10  Āḷavaka  —  A yakkha challenges the Buddha with riddles and threatens to “hurl out his mind, rip open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges” if he doesn’t solve the riddles to the yakkha’s satisfaction.

Title: Sn 1:11  Victory
column4: Sn 1:11  Victory  —  Victory over the defilements through contemplation of the unattractiveness of the body.

Title: Sn 1:12  The Sage
column4: Sn 1:12  The Sage  —  The characteristics of the ideal sage, who finds happiness and security in living the solitary life. (This sutta is apparently one of the series of passages that King Asoka recommended for study and reflection by all practicing Buddhists.)

Title: Sn 2:1  Treasures
column4: Sn 2:1  Treasures  —  The many treasures to be found in the Triple Gem.

Title: Sn 2:2  Raw Stench
column4: Sn 2:2  Raw Stench  —  People are defiled, not by eating meat, but by engaging in evil conduct.

Title: Sn 2:3  Shame
column4: Sn 2:3  Shame  —  How to recognize a true friend.

Title: Sn 2:4  Protection
column4: Sn 2:4  Protection  —  A list of the types of skillful behavior that give blessings and protection.

Title: Sn 2:5  Suciloma
column4: Sn 2:5  Suciloma  —  Another yakkha challenges the Buddha with riddles and threatens to “hurl out his mind, rip open his heart, or hurl him across the River Ganges” if he doesn’t solve the riddles to the yakkha’s satisfaction.

Title: Sn 2:6  The Dhamma Life
column4: Sn 2:6  The Dhamma Life  —  The Buddha encourages the monks to avoid monks who are evil in their desires.

Title: Sn 2:7  Brahman Principles
column4: Sn 2:7  Brahman Principles  —  How brahmans, through greed, abandoned the good principles of their ancestors.

Title: Sn 2:8  A Boat
column4: Sn 2:8  A Boat  —  A good teacher, like a good boatman, is one who knows firsthand how to cross to the further shore.

Title: Sn 2:9  With What Virtue?
column4: Sn 2:9  With What Virtue?  —  The attitudes and behavior that enable one best to learn and benefit from the Dhamma.

Title: Sn 2:10  Initiative
column4: Sn 2:10  Initiative  —  Get up! Don’t let the opportunity for practice pass you by.

Title: Sn 2:11  Rāhula
column4: Sn 2:11  Rāhula  —  Ven. Rāhula reflects on the teachings he received from his father, the Buddha.

Title: Sn 2:12  Vaṅgīsa
column4: Sn 2:12  Vaṅgīsa  —  Ven. Vaṅgīsa, the foremost poet among the Buddha’s disciples, praises the Buddha in verse.

Title: Sn 2:13  Right Wandering
column4: Sn 2:13  Right Wandering  —  The sort of person who, having gone forth, is fit to wander through the world.

Title: Sn 2:14  Dhammika
column4: Sn 2:14  Dhammika  —  The proper code of conduct for lay followers of the Dhamma.

Title: Sn 3:1  The Going Forth
column4: Sn 3:1  The Going Forth  —  The young Bodhisatta (Buddha-to-be), soon after leaving home, explains why he refuses King Bimbisāra’s offer of a position in his court.

Title: Sn 3:2  Exertion
column4: Sn 3:2  Exertion  —  Māra attempts to dissuade the Bodhisatta from his path.

Title: Sn 3:3  Well-spoken
column4: Sn 3:3  Well-spoken  —  Four characteristics of well-spoken speech.

Title: Sn 3:4  Sundarika Bhāradvāja
column4: Sn 3:4  Sundarika Bhāradvāja  —  A brahman questions the Buddha to see if the latter deserves to receive the cake resulting from his sacrifice.

Title: Sn 3:5  Māgha
column4: Sn 3:5  Māgha  —  What are the qualities of a recipient that produce the most merit from a gift?

Title: Sn 3:6  Sabhiya
column4: Sn 3:6  Sabhiya  —  A sutta dating from early in the Buddha’s teaching career. A wanderer, disappointed in the teachings he has received from other teachers, approaches the Buddha with his questions.

Title: Sn 3:7  Sela
column4: Sn 3:7  Sela  —  Sela the brahman praises the Buddha to see how the latter responds to praise.

Title: Sn 3:8  The Arrow
column4: Sn 3:8  The Arrow  —  Death and loss are inevitable, but grief is not.

Title: Sn 3:9  Vāseṭṭha
column4: Sn 3:9  Vāseṭṭha  —  Is one worthy of respect because of one’s birth, or because of one’s actions?

Title: Sn 3:10  Kokālika
column4: Sn 3:10  Kokālika  —  A follower of Devadatta slanders Ven. Sāriputta and Ven. Moggallāna and, after suffering a painful disease, falls into hell. The sutta then gives a graphic description of the sufferings awaiting him there.

Title: Sn 3:11  Nālaka
column4: Sn 3:11  Nālaka  —  A sutta in two parts. The first part gives an account of events soon after the birth of the Bodhisatta. The second part describes the way of the sage.

Title: Sn 3:12  The Contemplation of Dualities
column4: Sn 3:12  The Contemplation of Dualities  —  Not all dualities are misleading. This sutta teaches ways to contemplate the duality of the origination and cessation of stress and suffering so as to reach awakening.

Title: Introduction
column4: Introduction

Title: Sn 4:1  Sensual Pleasure
column4: Sn 4:1  Sensual Pleasure  —  The drawbacks of sensual desires.

Title: Sn 4:2  The Cave Octet
column4: Sn 4:2  The Cave Octet  —  Those who remain attached to the body, to sensuality, and to their sense of “mine” will have a hard time freeing themselves from fear of death and from further becoming.

Title: Sn 4:3  The Corrupted Octet
column4: Sn 4:3  The Corrupted Octet  —  Freedom isn’t to be found by boasting of your precepts and practices or by debating your views.

Title: Sn 4:4  The Pure Octet
column4: Sn 4:4  The Pure Octet  —  How to avoid the trap of letting go of one thing only to cling to something more subtle.

Title: Sn 4:5  The Supreme Octet
column4: Sn 4:5  The Supreme Octet  —  The conceit that comes from clinging to practices or views—even if they’re supreme—is a fetter preventing full freedom.

Title: Sn 4:6  Old Age
column4: Sn 4:6  Old Age  —  Life is short. Possessiveness brings grief. Freedom comes from abandoning any sense of “mine.”

Title: Sn 4:7  To Tissa-metteyya
column4: Sn 4:7  To Tissa-metteyya  —  The drawbacks of falling away from the celibate life.

Title: Sn 4:8  To Pasūra
column4: Sn 4:8  To Pasūra  —  The drawbacks of engaging in debates, for winners and losers alike.

Title: Sn 4:9  To Māgandiya
column4: Sn 4:9  To Māgandiya  —  Māgandiya offers the Buddha his daughter in marriage. The Buddha refuses and further subdues Māgandiya’s pride by describing a state of peace that Māgandiya doesn’t understand.

Title: Sn 4:10  Before the Break-up (of the Body)
column4: Sn 4:10  Before the Break-up (of the Body)  —  How to live at peace.

Title: Sn 4:11  Quarrels & Disputes
column4: Sn 4:11  Quarrels & Disputes  —  The Buddha is questioned on the source of quarrels and disputes, and on the highest level of spiritual attainment.

Title: Sn 4:12  The Lesser Array
column4: Sn 4:12  The Lesser Array  —  If the truth is one, how should a person behave in a world where many different truths are taught?

Title: Sn 4:13  The Great Array
column4: Sn 4:13  The Great Array  —  How to maintain freedom in a world full of disputes.

Title: Sn 4:14  Quickly
column4: Sn 4:14  Quickly  —  The attitudes and behavior of a monk training for the sake of total release.

Title: Sn 4:15  The Rod Embraced
column4: Sn 4:15  The Rod Embraced  —  The Buddha speaks in poignant terms of the saṁvega that led him to leave the household life. He concludes with recommendations for practice and a description of the person who has attained the goal of true peace and security.

Title: Sn 4:16  To Sāriputta
column4: Sn 4:16  To Sāriputta  —  When a monk, disaffected with the world, takes up the life of seclusion, what fears should he overcome? What dangers should he beware of? How should he train to blow away the impurities in his heart?

Title: Introduction
column4: Introduction

Title: Prologue
column4: Prologue  —  A brahman teacher sends his students to the Buddha to see if the latter is truly awakened.

Title: Sn 5:1  Ajita’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:1  Ajita’s Questions  —  A brahman questions the Buddha about mindfulness, discernment, and the cessation of name-and-form.

Title: Sn 5:2  Tissa-metteyya’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:2  Tissa-metteyya’s Questions  —  Who in the world is truly contented, truly free, truly a great person?

Title: Sn 5:3  Puṇṇaka’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:3  Puṇṇaka’s Questions  —  Birth and aging can be overcome, not through sacrificial rituals, but through training the mind to go beyond perturbation.

Title: Sn 5:4  Mettagū’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:4  Mettagū’s Questions  —  How does one cross the flood of birth and old age, sorrow and grief?

Title: Sn 5:5  Dhotaka’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:5  Dhotaka’s Questions  —  How can one become freed of all doubt?

Title: Sn 5:6  Upasīva’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:6  Upasīva’s Questions  —  What support should one hold on to in order to cross over the flood of craving? Can an awakened person be described?

Title: Sn 5:7  Nanda’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:7  Nanda’s Questions  —  Who deserves to be called a sage? Who has crossed over birth and aging?

Title: Sn 5:8  Hemaka’s Question
column4: Sn 5:8  Hemaka’s Question  —  How do you cross over entanglements in the world?

Title: Sn 5:9  Todeyya’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:9  Todeyya’s Questions  —  How to recognize an emancipated person.

Title: Sn 5:10  Kappa’s Question
column4: Sn 5:10  Kappa’s Question  —  What is the island above the flood of the great danger of birth?

Title: Sn 5:11  Jatukaṇṇin’s Question
column4: Sn 5:11  Jatukaṇṇin’s Question  —  How does one abandon birth and aging?

Title: Sn 5:12  Bhadrāvudha’s Question
column4: Sn 5:12  Bhadrāvudha’s Question  —  Bhadrāvudha asks the Buddha: How did you come to know the Dhamma?

Title: Sn 5:13  Udaya’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:13  Udaya’s Questions  —  How to reach unbinding and bring consciousness to a halt.

Title: Sn 5:14  Posāla’s Question
column4: Sn 5:14  Posāla’s Question  —  How to develop insight after mastering the perception of nothingness.

Title: Sn 5:15  Mogharāja’s Question
column4: Sn 5:15  Mogharāja’s Question  —  How should one view the world so as to escape the king of Death?

Title: Sn 5:16  Piṅgiya’s Questions
column4: Sn 5:16  Piṅgiya’s Questions  —  Alarmed by the deterioration of his aging body, Piṅgiya asks the Buddha how to conquer birth and decay.

Title: Epilogue
column4: Epilogue  —  Piṅgiya, after becoming a non-returner, explains to his former teacher his devotion to the Buddha.
